extra_meta.name: A-dam
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: A-dam is a fresh brand with character that creates quality products such as loungewear, intimates, and swimwear for him and her.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
A-dam's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its factories are certified by Social Accountability International - SA8000 and Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS). It does not disclose where its final stage of production occurs. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain.

This brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials so it is not applicable to rate its impact on animals. We calculate the overall rating from environment and labour scores only.

A-dam is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Just Jeans
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Just Jeans does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies .
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Just Jeans is owned by The Just Group.

Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It states it has a Code of Conduct but does not publicly share it. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It audits some of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather. It does not use fur, angora, down, wool, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

Just Jeans is rated 'We avoid' overall.

Last Updated: September 2020

extra_meta.name: FREITAG
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: FREITAG is a Swiss brand that creates one-of-a-kind bags and accessories from recycled truck tarp and fully compostable textiles.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
FREITAG's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including upcycled materials. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It does not disclose where all of its final stage of production occurs. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

FREITAG is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: heine
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: heine is not taking adequate steps to manage its greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
heine is owned by Otto Group.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. It has a general statement about eliminating hazardous chemical but no time-bound target.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a basic formal policy to protect animal welfare. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

heine is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: CKS does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
CKS is owned by FNG.

Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence that it investigates and reports on safety incidents. It does not disclose whether it pays a living wage at any stage of the supply chain. There is no evidence of listing names or addresses for any of its suppliers. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state which part and what percentage.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. However it uses leather and wool.

extra_meta.name: Know The Origin
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Know The Origin believes in style with nothing to hide for men and women.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Know The Origin's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. It uses low impact in all its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage. It audits or visits most of its suppliers.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

Know The Origin is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Principles
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Principles is not taking adequate steps to minimise textile waste in its supply chain.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Principles is owned by Debenhams.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations but it has not set a supply chain target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in part of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and down. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

Debenhams is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Last Updated: August 2020

extra_meta.name: Hamilton Perkins Collection
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Hamilton Perkins Collection makes designer travel bags made from recycled plastic bottles & repurposed billboard vinyl lining
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Hamilton Perkins Collection's environmental rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including recycled plastic bottles and billboards to make its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials reduces the amount of energy, water and chemicals used in its production processes.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It does not have an adequate Supplier Code of Conduct or any worker empowerment initiatives. However it sources its materials from 'Thread', which is a transparent and socially progressive supplier with a clear Code of Conduct and empowerment initiatives.

This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.

It is a certified B Corporation brand.

Hamilton Perkins Collection is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Portugal, a medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage.

extra_meta.name: Cotton On
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Cotton On is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Cotton On's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has initiatives to prevent human trafficking in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It does not use fur, down, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.

Cotton On is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: Hugo Boss
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Hugo Boss is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
HUGO BOSS's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses wool, leather, exotic animal hair and down. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

HUGO BOSS is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: Dotti
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Dotti does not provide sufficient information about its environmental policies
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Dotti is owned by Just Group.

Its environment rating is very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.

Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits some of its traced facilities over a two-year period across parts of its supply chain. However it has very few worker empowerment initiatives and it received a poor score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. It uses wool without specifying its sources.

Dotti is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

extra_meta.name: Liminal
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Sustainable, organic and Fairtrade clothing helping to economically empower women. Liminal have a wide range of organic cotton basics for men, women and children and specialise in custom print shirts and tote bags.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Liminal's environmental rating is 'great'. The majority of the brand's products are made from Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified cotton. While it does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions, its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact. Its use of Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) certified cotton and dyeing processes limits its use of hazardous chemicals, and reduces the brand's overall water usage.

Its labour rating is 'great'. The majority of Liminal's products are produced by Freeset, a WFTO Guarantee System certified producer. Other garments produced for the brand are made in WFTO Guarantee System, Fair Trade Federation, and Fairtrade International - Small Producers Organisations facilities, and therefore operate under robust Codes of Conduct. The use of WFTO Guarantee System certified facilities guarantees a living wage for their workers. It traces suppliers across its entire supply chain, and has created an interactive traceability map for some of its products. It is a leading advocate for better labour rights, and Freeset is an organisation which is devoted to helping women trapped in situations involving bonded labour and human trafficking.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, angora or leather but uses a small amount of wool in some products without providing information on sourcing.

Liminal is rated Great based on information from own research.

extra_meta.name: Nasty Gal
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Nasty Gal is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Nasty Gal's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals. It measures and reports greenhouse gas emissions from its direct operation but not its supply chain. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives.

Its labour rating is 'very poor'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Sedex Members Ethical Trade Audit - SMETA Best Practice Guidance in the final stage of production. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

Nasty Gal is rated 'We avoid' overall.

extra_meta.name: Puma
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Puma has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but it does not ensure payment of a living wage in its supply chain.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Puma's environment rating is 'it's a start'. Its tanneries are audited by the Leather Working Group. It is a member of the Better Cotton Initiative. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gases in its own operations by 35% by 2030 and reduce emissions in its supply chain by 60% per unit of revenue. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste in its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify if it uses unannounced audits.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool and down. It does not use fur, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora.

Puma is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: KITX
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Founded in 2014 by Kit Willow, KITX is a luxury designer fashion brand, created with sustainable materials and sourced consciously from around the world.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
KITX's environment rating is 'good'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It encourages consumers to reduce their climate impact when using its products. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in some of its products. It uses compostable packaging

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It does not disclose where all of its final stage of production occurs. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. There is no evidence it audits any of its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, exotic animal hair and silk. It does not use fur, down, exotic animal skin or angora.

KITX is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: Self Cinema
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Self Cinema is a Swedish denim brand built on the principles of being responsible, innovative and cool.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Self Cinema's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It uses renewable energy in its supply chain to reduce its climate impact. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its final stage of production is undertaken in the European Union, a low/medium risk country for labour abuse. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It audits some of its supply chain but does not state what percentage.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair or angora. It use wool certified by the Responsible Wool Standard.

Self Cinema is rated 'Good' overall.

Its labour rating is 'very poor'. Little of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather and wool. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal skin or hair. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

Eddie Bauer is rated 'We avoid' overall.

extra_meta.name: L'eggs
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: L'eggs traces most of its supply chain but does not use eco-friendly materials
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
L'eggs is owned by Hanesbrands Incorporated.

Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it recycles some off-cuts created during the manufacturing process. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it does not use any widely accepted tools to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions. It has made a public commitment to reduce its carbon emissions by 40% by the year 2020 and it has taken meaningful action on meeting its carbon reduction target. It complies with a Restricted Substances List however it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals from its supply chain. It measures and reports on water usage and wastewater management and publicly reports on targets.

Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It also traces most of its supply chain including all of its final stage, most of its inputs and some or none of its raw material stages. It publicly lists some of its suppliers and it ensures that no subcontracting occurs or that all subcontracted production adheres to code standards. It audits most of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its entire supply chain however it has very few worker empowerment initiatives. It received a good score in relation to implementing a living wage or improving wages across its supply chain.

This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labour scores only.

L'eggs is rated 'It's a start' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

extra_meta.name: AG Jeans
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: AG Jeans is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
AG Jeans's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. It implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.

Its labour rating is 'very poor'. It states it has a Code of Conduct but does not publicly share it. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It audits some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, exotic animal hair and wool. AG Jeans is rated 'We avoid' overall.

extra_meta.name: Mammut
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Mammut is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Mammut's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has a policy to prevent deforestation in the supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Fair Wear Foundation including most of the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather and wool. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, exotic animal hair, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

Mammut is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: Splendid
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Splendid uses animal products without specifying sources and there is not enough evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Splendid is owned by Delta Galil Industries.

Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste in the manufacturing part of its supply chain. However it does not use eco-friendly materials. It uses the GHG Protocol to guide measurement and reporting on its carbon emissions and it has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect emissions per product by 5% by 2016. The majority of its products are Oeko-Tex Standard 100 certified. It implements water reduction initiatives and publicly reports on targets however this only covers in-house manufacturing.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the FLA Workplace Code of Conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It mentions paying a living wage and supplies an adequate definition but it does not assure payment of a living wage. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear as to what extent. As of 2014, it claimed to have audited 80% of its manufacturing suppliers for human rights screening but it does not appear to use unannounced audits.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool from unspecified sources, and it uses angora and alpaca. However it does not use fur, down, shearling or exotic animal skin.

Splendid is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Zeeman
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Zeeman is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Zeeman's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has a general statement on reducing hazardous chemicals but it has not set a time-bound target. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in most of its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin, exotic animal hair and angora. It uses wool. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.

Zeeman is rated 'Not good enough' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: C&A
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: C&A uses eco-friendly materials but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
C&A's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. It implements some water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2020 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) including the final, second and first stages of production. It received a score of 61-70% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It does not disclose adequate policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of Covid-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

C&A is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: American Eagle
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: American Eagle is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
American Eagle is owned by AEO Inc.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it has taken meaningful action to reduce or eliminate hazardous chemicals.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 11-20% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes some information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not publish a list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, down and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

American Eagle is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: Lands' End
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Lands' End has not set specifc targets to reduce carbon emissions or water usage and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Lands' End environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it does offer a recycle program and reports on the percentage of production recovered. It does not measure or report on its direct and indirect emissions, or that of its supply chain although it has taken meaningful action to reduce energy and emissions in its operations. It does not measure or report on water usage and wastewater management.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust Supplier Code of Conduct that applies across the entire supply chain but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It traces suppliers in its supply chain but it is unclear to what extent and some of its supply chain is independently audited. It does not appear to use unannounced audits.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses wool and leather without stating it sources, and it uses down feather but 100% is accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use fur, angora, or exotic animal skin or hair.

Lands' End is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Piper
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Piper's environment policies do not extend far enough down the supply chain
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Piper is owned by Myers Holdings LimitedIts environment rating is not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it creates high-quality, long-lasting products and it is taking steps to reduce waste in its direct operations. It measures and reports on its direct and indirect emissions but does not do so for its entire supply chain and it has made no commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but it has set a target to reduce its energy intensity. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain or has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.

Its labour rating is not good enough' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces some of its supply chain including final stage, inputs and raw materials. It likely does not publicly list its suppliers but it does ensure that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits only a small portion of its traced facilities over a two-year period across its supply chain. It has minimal worker empowerment initiatives and has made little to no progress towards paying a living wage across its supply chain.

Its animal rating is it's a start'. It uses wool and leather without stating its sources. It does not use fur, angora, down or exotic animal skin or hair. Piper is rated Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:

Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impact on the environment.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It implements purchasing practices to help provide financial security for its suppliers. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces some of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses exotic animal hair and wool. extra_meta.name: Zella

extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Zella is owned by Nordstrom Inc.

Its environmental rating is 'not good enough', it is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP). It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear target. It has adopted the American Apparel and Footwear Association’s Restricted Substance List. However it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct based off the ILO Conventions, Fair labor Standards Act and UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. It is part of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety and Business for Social Responsibility (BSR) but it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It traces suppliers in part of its supply chain and some of its supply chain is independently audited. However there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers.

This brand does not use any animal derived materials. Since the brand makes products that are generally free of animal materials, we haven't awarded points. The total score is calculated from environment and labor scores only.

Zella is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on informational from our own research.

extra_meta.name: H&M
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: H&M publishes detailed information about its suppliers and supply chain policies but it creates short-lived, fast fashion products.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
H&M is owned by Hennes & Mauritz.

Its environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. Almost none of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 71-80% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audit and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production, some information about the second and first stages of production and detailed information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes detailed information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain however there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but implementation is uncertain.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

H&M is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Last Updated: July 2020

It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses some policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, down and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Balenciaga has good policies to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but uses fur, angora and exotic animal skin.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Balenciaga is owned by Kering.

Its environment rating is 'good'. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It reduces chromium and other hazardous chemicals from the leather tanning processes.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a robust policy to ensure animal welfare in its supply chain. It uses leather, down, fur, angora, exotic animal hair and exotic animal skin. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It traces most animal products to the first stage of production.

Balenciaga is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: Bonprix
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Bonprix is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Bonprix is owned by Otto Group.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. It has set a deadline to eliminate hazardous chemicals by 2030 but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by Business Social Compliance Initiative Code of Conduct - BSCI in the final stage of production. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a basic formal policy to protect animal welfare. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

Bonprix is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: Nau
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Nau creates premium apparel that blends technical performance & modern design, crafted from sustainably sourced materials
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Nau is owned by BlackYak.

Nau's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including organic cotton, Tencel and mechanically recycled polyester to create high-quality, long-lasting products. It does not seem to take specific steps to reduce energy use and carbon emissions, however its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact as well as the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production. It supports advocacy for better environmental outcomes by raising money for organisations who are creating lasting environmental change, including People for Bikes and the Conservation Alliance.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its labour policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on its labour practices.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses wool from non-mulesed sheep and alpaca without specifying its sources. It also uses recycled down. It does not use leather, angora, fur or exotic animal skin or hair.

Nau is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: R.M. Williams
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: R.M. Williams does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
R.M. Williams is owned by LVMH.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It does not use eco-friendly materials but it creates high-quality, long-lasting products and has a repair and reuse program in place. It does not have adequate policies on energy use and carbon emissions. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain including the environmental pollution of chromium and other chemicals from leather tanning processes. There is also no evidence it has adequate policies or initiatives on water usage and wastewater management.

Its labour rating is 'good' based on the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report. This looks at criteria including payment of a living wage, transparency and worker empowerment. It received the top score for its Supplier Code of Conduct included in its supplier contracts. It traces its final and input stages of its supply chain. It does not publicly list all of its suppliers but it ensures that none or only a small amount of subcontracting occurs. It audits all of its traced final stage facilities over a two-year period but does not do so for its entire input stage. It has some worker empowerment initiatives across parts of its supply chain. It has made minimal progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage across its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It also uses fur and exotic animal skins such as crocodile and exotic animal hair such as cashmere. It does not use down or angora.

R.M. Williams is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from the 2017 Ethical Fashion Report and our own research.

extra_meta.name: REEF
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: REEF has made a public commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions but is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
REEF is owned by VF Corporation.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set an absolute target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. There is no evidence it minimises packaging.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 51-60% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes detailed information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the findings of supplier audits. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather. It does not use angora, wool, exotic animal hair, fur, down or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal product to the first stage of production.

REEF is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: Outerknown
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Outerknown is a sustainable clothing brand established from an understated approach to design and an overstated approach to quality, material and consciousness.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Outerknown's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including GOTS cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in most of its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain. It audits some of its suppliers.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It does not use fur, leather, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses wool and exotic animal hair.

Outerknown is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: New Look
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: New Look is not taking adequate steps to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
New Look's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It has fast fashion traits such as on trend styles and regular new arrivals. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather, down and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. It has committed to reduce the use of animal products

New Look is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Last Updated: August 2020

extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: American Rag is not taking adequate steps to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain and there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
American Rag is owned by Macy’s, Inc.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It offers a recycle program but does not report on the percentage of production recovered. It is taking steps to implement a strategy to reduce waste across its supply chain. It does not measure or report on its direct and indirect emissions however it has made a public commitment to reduce its emissions by another 2% per year in 2017 and 2018. It claims to be taking steps to meet its carbon reduction target but is not fully transparent about how. There is no evidence it is taking adequate steps to minimise or eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain. It claims to have water reduction targets and initiatives but these are not public. It is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a supplier Code of Conduct based on the Ethical Trading Initiative Code but it is unclear if it applies to all of its supply chain. There is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not adequately trace suppliers in its supply chain or publicly share a list of its suppliers, however some of its supply chain is independently audited and it uses unannounced audits.

Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.

American Rag is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Forever 21
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Forever 21 does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental policies .
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Forever 21's environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.

Its labour rating is 'very poor'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 0-10% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It publishes zero or very limited information about its supplier policies and audits. It does not disclose any information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It does not use fur, angora, leather, down or exotic animal skin. It uses wool and exotic animal hair. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

Forever 21 is rated 'We avoid' overall.

extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Outland Denim's environment rating is 'great'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all of its products. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'great'. It is a social enterprise that assists in creating employment opportunities for women who have been trafficked in Cambodia. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

Outland Denim is rated 'Great' overall.

extra_meta.name: Ruby & Bloom
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Ruby & Bloom does not use any animal products but there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Ruby & Bloom is owned by Nordstrom Inc.

Its environmental rating is 'not good enough', it is a member of the Sustainable Apparel Coalition and the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP). It has made a public commitment to reduce its direct and indirect carbon emissions but has not yet set a clear target. It has adopted the American Apparel and Footwear Association’s Restricted Substance List. However it has made no commitment to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It has a Supplier Code of Conduct based off the ILO Conventions, Fair labor Standards Act and UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. It is part of the Alliance for Bangladesh Worker Safety and Business for Social Responsibility (BSR) but it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. It traces suppliers in part of its supply chain and some of its supply chain is independently audited. However there is no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers.

Its animal rating is 'great'. It does not use any animal products.

Ruby & Bloom is rated 'It's a start' based on informational from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Aiayu
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Aiayu is a Danish brand that uses fashion to recycle and reuse fabrics, creating a zero waste programme for all organic cotton products.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Aiayu's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It reuses some of its offcuts to minimise textile waste. It reduces its water use by using recycled water. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its facilities are certified by Worldwide Responsible Accredited Production - WRAP or Social Accountability International - SA8000. It monitors health and safety issues with an internal procedure. There is no evidence it has a Code of Conduct but it has a formal statement covering workers rights. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain but does not specify what percentage. It traces all of its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use fur, leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin or angora. It uses exotic animal hair.

Aiayu is rated 'Good' overall.

It manages the treatment and discharge of wastewater in its supply chain. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. Its facilities are certified by Ethical Clothing Australia. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production. It visits its suppliers regularly.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use leather, down, angora, exotic animal skin or exotic animal hair. It uses recycled wool.

A.BCH is rated 'Great' overall.

There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses leather, wool and down. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

HEMA is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: STANLEY/STELLA
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: STANLEY/STELLA provides garments to a network of retailers, textile branding specialists, events agencies and experts in promotional objects.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
STANLEY/STELLA's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS) cotton. It uses low impact non-toxic dyes in all its products. There is no evidence it minimises packaging. There is no evidence it is taking specific steps to reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions. However its use of eco-friendly materials reduces its climate impact and limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'good'. It is a member of the Fair Wear Foundation. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO Four Fundamental Freedoms principles. It monitors health and safety issues through an third party audit of its final stage of production suppliers. It sources its final stage of production from countries with extreme risk of labour abuse. It ensures payment of a living wage in some of its supply chain. It traces most of its supply chain including all of the final stage of production.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

STANLEY/STELLA is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain. There is no evidence it has set a greenhouse gas emissions reduction target. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Some of its supply chain is certified by FLA Workplace Code of Conduct including all of the final stage of production. It received a score of 21-30% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It does not publish a comprehensive list of suppliers or information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It is unclear whether it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It does not disclose any policies or safeguards to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal skin or exotic animal hair. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It uses leather and wool.

extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:

Its labour rating is 'not good enough' based on the 2018 Ethical Fashion Report. It has no worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It traces only some of its supply chain and it does not publicly list its suppliers. It audits only a small proportion of its traced facilities. It has a Code of Conduct that covers all of the ILO principles however it has made little to no progress towards ensuring payment of a living wage.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It publishes some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and exotic animal hair. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, down or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production .

Timberland is rated 'It's a start' overall.

extra_meta.name: Maiyet
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Maiyet is a modern, luxury fashion brand for women that partners with global artisans to incorporate exquisitely handcrafted details into its collections
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Maiyet's environment rating is 'not good enough'. It acknowledges the importance of sustainably sourced materials however it does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its production practices impacts on the environment.

Its labour rating is 'good'. It works with a range of artisans from many different countries and has partnered with Nest, an independent not-for-profit organisation that trains and develops artisan businesses. It has good worker empowerment initiatives across some of its supply chain. It sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labour abuse but attempts to address those risks through the Positive Luxury's 'butterfly mark' which states that the brand takes into account a range of labour policies and initiatives such as having no forced labour and equal employment. It also mentions payment of a fair wage but does not define this. It traces suppliers in its supply chain however there is no evidence that it adequately audits its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It uses leather and wool without stating its sources. It also uses hair from exotic animals such cashmere, mohair and alpaca. However it has worked with the nomadic goat herders of Outer Mongolia to create FAIR, the world's first ethically sourced and environmentally sustainable cashmere yarn in the world.

Maiyet is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

Its environment rating is 'very poor'. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It covers most workers rights principles in its code of conduct. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. However, it does not provide a Supplier Code of Conduct and no evidence it provides a living wage for its workers. It does not appear to audit or visit any of its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses wool without stating its sources but does not use leather, fur, angora, down feather or exotic animal skin or hair.

Zen Nomad is rated 'It's a start' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: A New Day
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: A New Day is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
A New Day is owned by Target Corporation.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain but there is no evidence it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 31-40% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It likely publishes a list of suppliers in the final stage of production but not the second stage. It may be publishing limited information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19 but not workers.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses wool, leather, down and exotic animal hair. It does not use fur, angora or exotic animal skin. There is no evidence it traces any animal products to the first stage of production.

A New Day is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Most of its final stage of production is undertaken in Italy, a medium risk country for labour abuse. Its animal rating is 'very poor'. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the suffering of animals. It uses leather, wool, down, exotic animal skin and exotic animal hair. It does use fur or angora. There is no evidence it traces animal products to the first stage of production.

extra_meta.name: Onitsuka Tiger
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Onitsuka Tiger is not taking adequate steps to ensure payment of a living wage for its workers.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Onitsuka Tiger is owned by Asics.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses few eco-friendly materials. There is no evidence it has a policy to minimise the impacts of microplastics. It has set a science-based target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions generated from its own operations and supply chain and it is on track to meet its target. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. There is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It does not disclose which animal products it uses.

Onitsuka Tiger is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: ORTOVOX
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: ORTOVOX is not taking adequate steps to manage its greenhouse gas emissions.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
ORTOVOX is owned by Schwan-Stabilo.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including recycled materials. There is no evidence it reduces its carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions in its supply chain. There is no evidence it implements water reduction initiatives in its supply chain. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products.

Its labour rating is 'it's a start'. It is a member of the Fair Wear Foundation. There is no evidence it has worker empowerment initiatives such as collective bargaining or rights to make a complaint. It has a project to improve wages in some of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It has a general statement about minimising animal suffering but not a formal animal welfare policy. It uses wool, leather and down. It does not use fur, angora, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

ORTOVOX is rated 'Not good enough' overall.

extra_meta.name: MELAWEAR
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: MELAWEAR is a clothing brand that utilises GOTS certified organic cotton for all its pieces.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
MELAWEAR's environment rating is 'good'. Its products are certified by Global Organic Textile Standard (GOTS). There is no evidence it minimises textile waste. Its use of eco-friendly materials limits the amount of chemicals, water and wastewater used in production.

Its labour rating is 'great'. Its products are certified by [FT textile] and Fairtrade International - Small Producers Organisations. It traces all of its supply chain. It ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It audits most of its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It does not use any animal products but it does not state that it's vegan.

MELAWEAR is rated 'Good' overall.

extra_meta.name: G-Star RAW
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: G-Star RAW has good policies to eliminate hazardous chemicals in its supply chain but is not taking adequate steps to reduce textile waste in its supply chain.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
G-Star RAW's environment rating is 'it's a start'. It uses some eco-friendly materials including organic cotton. It has eliminated hazardous chemicals for most of the final and second stages of production. There is no evidence it minimises textile waste when manufacturing its products. It has a policy approved by CanopyStyle to prevent deforestation of ancient and endangered forests in its supply chain.

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. None of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It received a score of 41-50% in the Fashion Transparency Index. It likely publishes information about its supplier policies, audits and remediation processes. It publishes a detailed list of suppliers in the final stage of production and some information about the second stage of production. It may be publishing some information about forced labour, gender equality or freedom of association. It has a project to improve wages in its supply chain but there is no evidence it ensures payment of a living wage in most of its supply chain. It discloses policies to protect suppliers and workers in its supply chain from the impacts of COVID-19.

Its animal rating is 'it's a start'. It has a formal animal welfare policy aligned with Five Freedoms. It uses leather and down. It states that it sources wool from non-mulesed sheep. It does not use angora, fur, exotic animal hair or exotic animal skin. It has committed to eliminating down by a specific date.

G-Star RAW is rated 'It's a start' overall.

Last Updated: August 2020

extra_meta.name: Prairie Underground
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Prairie Underground is a populist apparel manufacturer committed to designing modern uniforms that evoke sensuality in daily self-expression.
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Prairie Underground's environment rating is 'good'. It uses a high proportion of eco-friendly materials including hemp and organic cotton, and a small proportion of non eco-friendly materials including conventional cotton and virgin polyester. It reduces its carbon footprint by manufacturing close to its main retail outlets. It claims to be committed to eliminating hazardous chemicals and uses recycled water for all of its dyeing.

Its labor rating is 'it's a start'. Its second and final stage of production is done in the USA, a medium risk country for labor rights. It works closely with its producers and traces suppliers in most of its supply chain. However, it does not have an adequate Supplier Code of Conduct or worker empowerment initiatives and there is no evidence that it audits or visits its supply chain.

Its animal rating is 'good'. It uses wool without stating its sources. It does not use fur, leather, down feathers, angora or exotic animal skin and hair.

Prairie Underground is rated 'Good' based on information from our own research.

extra_meta.name: Lauren
extra_meta.ethicalInfo1: Lauren does not communicate sufficient information about its environmental and labor policies
extra_meta.ethicalInfo2:
Lauren is owned by Ralph Lauren Corporation.

Its environment rating is 'not good enough'. It claims to be taking steps to meet its carbon reduction target, but is not fully transparent about how. It measures and reports on its direct emissions only. It does not publish sufficient relevant information about its environmental policies to give a higher rating. As a shopper you have the right to know how its products impact on the environment.

Its labor rating is 'not good enough'. It is taking steps to create a robust Supplier Code of Conduct. It traces suppliers in all of its supply chain and tracks the use of temporary or contract workers. However it sources from countries with high or extreme risk of labor abuse. AIl of its supply chain is independently audited once a year by third party or internal auditors that are accredited in social auditing and it uses unannounced audits. However there is no evidence that it provides a living wage for its workers.

Its animal rating is 'not good enough'. It uses leather, wool, and down feather without specifying its sources. It also uses the exotic animal hairs cashmere and mohair. It has banned the use of angora and fur in its products.

Lauren is rated 'Not Good Enough' based on the information from our own research.

Last Updated: March 2017

extra_meta.name: Superdry

Its labour rating is 'not good enough'. Little of its supply chain is certified by labour standards which ensure worker health and safety, living wages or other labour rights. It uses down accredited by the Responsible Down Standard. It does not use angora, fur or exotic animal skin. It traces some animal products to the first stage of production.

Superdry is rated 'Not good enough' overall.
